awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
The Steering Committee of the Southern Biomedical Engineering Conference (SBEC) will host a conference meeting from August 25th to 28th in New Orleans, Louisiana, on the rapidly growing interdisciplinary field of biomedical science and engineering. This conference strongly supports and promotes the research engagement of students, especially ones who are not well-funded, under-represented, or otherwise not likely to be able to attend conferences. The mission of the conference is to encourage students to pursue cutting-edge research in the field. NSF funding will be used exclusively to support conference registration fees and their other related costs (e.g., logistics and travel, etc.) for URM researchers. Eight to ten underrepresented minority (URM) students from multiple universities will be supported to attend this conference. These students will present papers and posters at the conference, and their abstracts will be published in the yearly issue of SBEC proceedings.

Technical Abstract: 
This award will increase the participation from underrepresented minority (URM) communities at the 38th Southern Biomedical Engineering Conference (New Orleans, LA; August 25-28, 2022). The goals of this conference include exchanging knowledge while gaining a better perspective on the advances in the field of biomedical science and engineering, and discussing the issues faced by clinicians and researchers. Several topics including biomaterials and their applications in implants, tissue engineering, drug delivery etc., presented at this conference will help researchers, engineers, and clinicians find balance between innovative technology and the human side of medical care. In keeping with the emphasis on student participation, the SBEC will provide best paper and presentation awards to undergraduate, graduate, and professional students. Student testimonials will be collected to assess and summarize the impact of attending this conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The support from NSF-BMAT Program helped good number of underrepresented minority (URM) students to participate in this conference. SBEC program committee formed a selection committee to identify the URM researchers from multiple institutions. The committee was chaired by Dr. Bhattarai (PI of this grant) and two organizing committee members (Dr. Benghuzzi-Mississippi Academy of Sciences and Dr. Tucci-University of Mississippi). The funding was used exclusively for URM researchers conference registrations and their other related costs (e.g., logistics and travel, etc.). Selected number of URM student researchers were identified from these institutions, NC A&T State University, Southeastern Louisiana University, University of Mississippi Medical Center and Dillard University.  Total of six (6) minority students (four undergraduate research students and two grad students). Five students presented their research poster, and one student gave oral presentation. Two of them received best presentation awards in undergraduate and graduate students? categories. All the recipients were recognized with a certificate SBEC registration fellowship at the last day of the conference.

Following URM students were supported from this grant.

1.     Felix Tettey (PhD student from NC A&T State University,).

All the expenses including conference registration, hotel, airfare, food etc. were covered by this grant. Major accomplishments: He submitted one abstract to give oral presentation and one abstract for poster presentation.

2.     Dekonti Davies (PhD student from NC A&T State University). Conference registration was covered by this grant.

3.     Mackenzie Long (Undergraduate student from NC A&T State University). Conference registration was covered by this grant.

4.    Mr. Sean Reliford (Undergraduate student from Southeastern Louisiana University).

Conference registration was covered by this grant. Major accomplishments: Presented a research poster titled "Diastereoselective aldol reactions of n,n-dialkylphenylacetamides towards the synthesis of building blocks of bioactive compounds". He received best poster presentation award.

6.    Aswin Arunachalam, undergraduate student from Mississippi INBRE Research Scholar program at University of Mississippi Medical Center. Major accomplishments: Reduction in Uterine Perfusion-induced Intrauterine Growth Restriction Enhances Susceptibility to Ischemic Stroke-Induced Neurobehavioral Deficits and Brain Damage in Adult Rats

7.     Kiarston Blackman, undergraduate student from Dillard University. Conference registration was covered by this grant. Major accomplishments: Assessment of cardiovascular disease impact perception in southern HBCU students.

 Additional Impact

Conference was led by faculty from HBCU:  

 Dr. Narayan Bhattarai, Professor of Bioengineering at NC A&T State University and Director of Biomaterials for Tissue Engineering Lab was the chair of 38th SBEC.  Dr. Bhattarai is Coordinator of Bioengineering Undergraduate Program at NC A&T State University, the first ABET-accredited program at an Historically Black College and University (HBCU). In the past, he has served the SBEC as program co-chair, session organizer, and abstract reviewer. Co-chairs of 38th SBEC will be Dr. Alan Eberhardt, Professor and Associate Chair of Education at University of Alabama at Birmingham, and Dr. Lir-Wan Fan, Professor at University of Mississippi Medical Center. Dr. Bhattarai involved significant number of participants from his institution.  

Major highlights for NC A&T State University:

1.    Our graduate student received Excellence in Research Award:

Felix Tettey (MS in Bioengineering, PhD student in Industrial System Engineering) is the recipient of the SBEC 2022 Subrata Saha Excellence in Research Award (cash and certificate). This is given to only one student who receives the highest score regardless of any category in the competition. FYI, Dr. Subrata Saha is the founder of this conference.

2.    Two Keynote talks from NC A&T Professors (Dr. Salil Desai and Dr. Yeoheung Yun)

3.    Three Sessions were organized and moderated by NC A& T Professors (Dr. Eunsoo Yoo and Dr. Bishnu Bastakoti)

4.    Four podium talks and several poster presentations by NC A&T?s students and faculty (Dr. Chandrasekaran)

5.    Two Guilford County Highschool students who did their summer research at NC A& T Professor?s lab presented their research posters.

6.    NC A&T?s was one of the major sponsors of the event

Complete proceeding of SBEC 2022 is available here. Also, please find couple snapshots of the event in the attachments.

https://sbec18.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Proceedings-of-the-Thirty-eighth-SBEC-2022-Published-on-8_17FF.pdf

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2023
Modified by: Narayan Bhattarai
